critique: This document pertains to the inspection of tax returns by a Senate committee investigating lobbying activities. It is difficult to assess its position on the traditional left-right political spectrum. The document does not directly address immigration. It could be argued that allowing a Senate committee access to tax returns expands executive power, as the order is issued by the executive branch. However, it could also be seen as a check on corporate power and lobbying, thus serving the public interest. The document does not directly address federalism. It does not directly address national security or civil liberties. The document could be seen as increasing government intervention in the economy by allowing investigation of lobbying activities related to financial matters. The document does not directly address social inclusion.
